p: Myrtle is considered as an important source of phenolic compounds with several health benefits like antioxidant, antimicrobial and anti-viral activities [ 16, 17]. It is well-know that the amount of active secondary metabolites may vary depending on the plant organ, the season, the geographical area and the extraction technique. Myrtle leavesâ€™ extracts were demonstrated to have the highest content in polyphenols as compared to flower buds and berries [ 18]. The active ingredients in myrtle can be classified into three main groups: (i) phenolic acids (Gallic acid, Syringic acid, Vanillic acid and Ferulic acid), (ii) flavonoids (Myricetin, Myricetin-3- O-galactoside, Myricetin-3- O-ramnoside, Quercetin, Quercetin-3- d-galactoside and Quercetin-3- d-rahmnoside), and (iii) tannins (Gallotannins and Catechin) [ 18].
